stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the visual design of a large desert level, focusing on solving the 'bottomless pit' problem. He experimented with fog, a custom procedural skybox, and parallaxing background geometry to create a sense of scale. The stream also included performance testing on N64 hardware, which revealed surprisingly good results even without key optimizations enabled.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's development process is highly iterative, involving experimentation, observation, and refinement to solve design and technical challenges.
development_findings.quote: These are the kind of things where you just have to try, see what happens, see how it turns out, I find.

development_findings.summary: An early decision to use a specific blue fog color is now considered a core, unchangeable part of the level's artistic identity.
development_findings.quote: The fog color right now is very essential for the art style here. Making it all yellow would change the vibe a lot... It is too late to undo that.

development_findings.summary: The project is so highly optimized that it has created a unique performance bottleneck, shifting the processing strain from the RDP to the RSP, which requires a custom version of the F3dx3 microcode from collaborator Sauron.
development_findings.quote: He said he thinks that in Return to Yoshi's Island the memory and RDP is so optimized that with F3dx3 the RSP becomes the bottleneck.

development_findings.summary: Kaze discovered the level runs at a surprisingly high framerate (25-30 FPS) on N64 hardware even with crucial optimizations like object culling disabled, indicating the engine is more efficient than anticipated.
development_findings.quote: Wait a second, you see that? Enable Culling isn't even on... How the fuck is it running?

development_findings.summary: Kaze rejects a suggestion for a second transparent, moving sand layer, citing it would be too computationally expensive ('overdrawing everything twice') for the N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: You can't do that. Not on the N64, otherwise that would be a pretty nice idea.

development_findings.summary: A key technical constraint is the inability to use shade alpha globally, which complicates effects like fog and blending.
development_findings.quote: Man, not being able to use shade alpha throughout the entire level is such a big limitation.

development_findings.summary: The team is waiting on an updated version of the F3dx3 microcode from Sauron, which is expected to provide a 'huge performance boost' by optimizing for the RSP.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has been approached by a company to develop a commercial N64 game, seeing it as a massive marketing opportunity due to its novelty.
context_findings.quote: A company that approached me recently and they said they want to make an N64 game in 2024. Looks like they might be doing it, but we'll find out in June.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses frustration with the prevalence of online 'rage bait' and drama, preferring to ignore it, a philosophy he calls 'The power of not caring'.
context_findings.quote: I feel like almost every video I am recommended by youtube is some meaningless drama... Are humans just hardwired to be into that shit?

context_findings.summary: Kaze has ambitions to release a physical version of the game's soundtrack on a cartridge, indicating the importance of the music to the project.
context_findings.quote: I'm hoping that I can release RTYI alongside an OST cartridge.

context_findings.summary: Kaze observes that his Discord community is currently experiencing pointless arguments and speculation.
context_findings.quote: People are arguing about nothing in my discord nowadays and then people are just making unfounded assumptions.

biobak.summary: Biobak, a key graphics artist, has been unexpectedly absent from the project.
biobak.quote: Dude, has anyone seen Biobak recently? He's been gone for a while. He wanted to help me rework a bunch of levels.

biobak.summary: Kaze expresses concern over Biobak's absence, indicating he is a critical team member whose unavailability poses a risk to the project.
biobak.quote: I hope he's not gone. That'd be really unfortunate for the case empire.

badub.summary: Kaze states that Badub has taken full ownership of the soundtrack and intends to compose all the music for the game.
badub.quote: The reason you are not the first person to ask to compose for RTYI is because my dupe wants to make all of it.

badub.summary: The in-game music is a 'midi-fied' version of the original compositions, resulting in a lower fidelity sound compared to the standalone tracks.
badub.quote: A lot of the music in the game obviously is midi-fied, so it's going to not sound as good as on SoundCloud.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions playing games with his wife, Zeina, but provides no new details about her professional contributions to the project in this stream.
zeina.quote: I played it with my wife. It was unplayable even with two people.

key_stories.title: The Bottomless Sky Solution
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to solve the 'bottomless pit' problem for a desert level. After several failed attempts, he engineered a multi-layered solution with a custom fog, a procedural cloudscape, and parallaxing background cliffs, creating a sense of vast, open space.
key_stories.challenge: The desert level looked like it was floating in an empty void. Early attempts to fill the space with quicksand looked terrible and felt wrong.
key_stories.process: Kaze iterated through multiple solutions, rejecting quicksand and complex fading effects. He drew inspiration from F-Zero and Kalimari Desert, deciding to create large, distant cliff models on a separate layer for a parallax effect. He then meticulously tweaked the level's fog color to perfectly match the cliffs, creating a seamless blend between the playable area and the distant background.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a visually cohesive and unique background that gives a sense of immense scale, using a custom fog color, a math-based cloudscape below, and parallaxing background cliffs that blend seamlessly into the fog.
key_stories.key_quote: It would be very cool if we could somehow connect the sand on our floor with the skybox. You know what I mean?

key_stories.title: The Accidental Performance Win
key_stories.summary: While testing a large level on real hardware, Kaze was worried about performance. He was shocked to discover that a key optimization, object culling, was accidentally turned off, yet the game still ran at a nearly stable 30 FPS, proving his engine was far more capable than he'd realized.
key_stories.challenge: A large, graphically-intensive level posed a significant performance risk, with concerns that it wouldn't run at a stable 30 FPS on original N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze built the level with optimizations like occlusion culling in mind. To get a true benchmark, he tested the level on a real N64. During the test, he realized the culling feature wasn't even active, meaning the console was rendering thousands of unnecessary polygons, yet still maintaining a playable framerate.
key_stories.outcome: The level performed remarkably well, holding 25-30 FPS on a real N64 even without the planned optimizations. This was a major technical victory and a testament to the engine's efficiency, promising even better performance in the final version.
key_stories.key_quote: Wait a second, you see that? Enable Culling isn't even on. We're not even culling these buildings... How the fuck is it running?

key_stories.title: The Sauron Bottleneck
key_stories.summary: Kaze's project was so optimized it created a new, unforeseen performance issue with an advanced graphics microcode. After collaborating with its creator, Sauron, they realized the game was pushing the N64 in a new way, requiring a custom-tailored version of the microcode to unlock even greater performance.
key_stories.challenge: The project was experiencing unique lag issues with the advanced F3dx3 microcode that other projects weren't, and the cause was unknown.
key_stories.process: Kaze collaborated with Sauron, the creator of F3dx3, to diagnose the problem. Sauron theorized that Kaze's engine was so efficient at using the N64's graphics processor (RDP) that the bottleneck had shifted to a different processor (the RSP), which F3dx3 relies on more heavily.
key_stories.outcome: Sauron is developing a custom version of F3dx3 with reduced RSP overhead specifically for this project. This collaboration will likely lead to a significant performance increase and represents the project pushing the known limits of the N64.
key_stories.key_quote: He said he thinks that in Return to Yoshi's Island the memory and RDP is so optimized that with F3dx3 the RSP becomes the bottleneck.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that Biobak, the graphics artist planned to 'rework a bunch of levels,' has been absent for a while, and that his absence would be 'really unfortunate.'
questions: How does Biobak's absence affect the project's visual direction and timeline?
What was the original plan for the levels he was going to rework?
How does the team adapt when a key contributor becomes unexpectedly unavailable?

open_questions.context: Kaze revealed that a company approached him with an offer to develop a new, commercial game for the N64, with more news expected in June.
questions: What can you share about this potential commercial project?
How does the possibility of this new venture influence your work and focus on RTYI?
What are the major legal and logistical hurdles in producing and selling a physical N64 game today?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated that Badub 'wants to make all of' the music for the game and that he hopes to release a physical OST cartridge.
questions: Can you describe the collaborative process with Badub for creating the game's score?
How are musical themes decided for different levels?
What would be involved in producing a physical OST cartridge for the N64?

open_questions.topic: F3dx3 Optimization and Collaboration with Sauron
open_questions.context: Kaze explained a complex performance issue where his game's high optimization created an 'RSP bottleneck' with the F3dx3 microcode, requiring a custom fix from its creator, Sauron.
questions: Could you explain in simpler terms what the 'RSP bottleneck' means and why it's unique to your project?
What new visual or performance capabilities do you hope this new version of F3dx3 will unlock?
How important is this kind of technical collaboration with other experts in the romhacking community?

open_questions.context: Zeina is a known animator on the team and Kaze's wife, but her direct contributions were not discussed in this stream.
questions: How do you and Zeina navigate the dynamic of being both spouses and collaborators on a major project?
Can you share an example of how Zeina's animation work has solved a gameplay problem or enhanced a character's feel?
What is her role in the day-to-day development process?
